elements.content: Four new coordination polymer compounds have been prepared using 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (AmTRZ) as an organic linker, namely, ZnCl(AmTRZ) (1), Zn(HCO2)(AmTRZ) (2), Zn5(OH)2(AmTRZ)6(NO3)2·6H2O (3), and Zn5(OH)(AmTRZH)(AmTRZ)6(HCO2)3·5H2O (4). They were synthesized under mild hydro- or solvothermal conditions using water or dimethylformamide as solvent. Their crystal structures were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques, and thermal properties of all compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis. Isostructural compounds 1 and 2 (Pbca, a = 9.389(1) Å, b = 10.115(1) Å, c = 11.571(2) Å, V = 1098.9(3) Å3, Z = 8 for 1 and a = 9.198(1) Å, b = 10.341(1) Å, c = 12.577(2) Å, V = 1196.2(3) Å, Z = 8 for 2) display a two-dimensional layer structure where Zn centers are linked by AmTRZ molecules to form gridlike layers containing eight-membered rings. Structure 3 (Pa3̄, a = 15.0448(6) Å, V = 3405.3(2) Å3, Z = 4) is a dense three-dimensional framework, featuring seven-membered channels where water and nitrate anions are located. Structure 4 (I4/m, a = 19.2576(9) Å, c = 20.286(2) Å, V = 7523.2(9) Å3, Z = 8) is built from porous Zn−AmTRZ layers containing 12- and 8-membered rings, which are connected to each other by dinuclear Zn tetrahedra building units. Water and formate anions occupy the void inside the framework.

elements.content: Four new Zn-based metal−organic frameworks have been synthesized using 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole as a ligand under solvothermal conditions. Their crystal structures were characterized in detail by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Their thermal properties were also studied by thermogravimetric analysis.
elements.clean_text: Four new Zn-based metal-organic frameworks have been synthesized using 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole as a ligand under solvothermal conditions. Their crystal structures were characterized in detail by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Their thermal properties were also studied by thermogravimetric analysis.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of metal−organic hybrid frameworks (MOFs) have progressed extensively in recent years. These coordination polymers, built from metal ions and rigid organic bridging ligands, often contain large pores or channels that can give rise to interesting physical properties. Many MOFs have been thoroughly studied for their potential applications in the areas of gas sorption, ion-exchange, sensors, and catalysis. Because the formation of MOFs is a complex process, it is not trivial to rationally predict and design a new structure with the desired physical properties. A recent method proposed by Férey and co-workers addresses this problem by combining the exploratory synthesis with computer simulations.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of metal-organic hybrid frameworks (MOFs) have progressed extensively in recent years. These coordination polymers, built from metal ions and rigid organic bridging ligands, often contain large pores or channels that can give rise to interesting physical properties. Many MOFs have been thoroughly studied for their potential applications in the areas of gas sorption, ion-exchange, sensors, and catalysis. Because the formation of MOFs is a complex process, it is not trivial to rationally predict and design a new structure with the desired physical properties. A recent method proposed by Férey and co-workers addresses this problem by combining the exploratory synthesis with computer simulations.

elements.content: While a wide variety of organic molecules are available as linkers, aromatic polycarboxylates and pyridines are most broadly used for the construction of MOFs because of their structural rigidity and flexible coordination modes. However, the application of the linkers with diverse functionalities can be very advantageous when designing interesting multidimensional architectures. Polyaza heterocycles, such as 1,2,4-triazole (TRZ), are examples of such linkers because they contain three potential metal binding sites, which can yield the formation of a MOF through multiple bonding interactions. A number of metal−triazolate compounds have been prepared using this ligand, and their properties have been examined. Functionalized TRZ ligands have also been employed to create MOFs with fascinating architectures. For instance, the application of a monosubstituted triazole, 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (AmTRZ), resulted in various MOFs such as Ag6Cl(AmTRZ)4(OH) and ZnF(AmTRZ). Moreover, the unsymmetrical shape of AmTRZ has led to the formation of a chiral framework, CdCl(AmTRZ).

Moreover, the unsymmetrical shape of AmTRZ has led to the formation of a chiral framework, CdCl(AmTRZ).

elements.content: As a part of our continuing effort to discover MOFs with interesting crystal chemistry and physical properties, we have investigated the formation of new coordination polymers in the Zn−AmTRZ system. This work describes the synthesis of four new Zn−AmTRZ frameworks, including ZnCl(AmTRZ) (1), Zn(HCO2)(AmTRZ) (2), Zn5(OH)2(AmTRZ)6(NO3)2·6H2O (3), and Zn5(OH)(AmTRZH)(AmTRZ)6(HCO2)3·5H2O (4). Their crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques, and their thermal properties were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis. This work also illustrates the effects of the changes in reaction conditions on the resulting structures.

Their crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques, and their thermal properties were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis. This work also illustrates the effects of the changes in reaction conditions on the resulting structures.

elements.content: General Procedures. All four compounds were synthesized under hydro- or solvothermal conditions in 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr autoclaves. Starting materials include zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 99%, Alfa-Aesar), 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole-5-carboxylic acid hydrate (AmTRZAc, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich), triethylamine (TEA, 99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich) and N,N‘-dimethylformamide (Sigma-Aldrich). It was found that the AmTRZAc ligand undergoes decarboxylation to generate AmTRZ under hydrothermal reaction conditions. After reaction, the products were filtered, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried in air.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Procedures. All four compounds were synthesized under hydro- or solvothermal conditions in 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr autoclaves. Starting materials include zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 99%, Alfa-Aesar), 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole-5-carboxylic acid hydrate (AmTRZAc, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich), triethylamine (TEA, 99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich) and N,N‘-dimethylformamide (Sigma-Aldrich). It was found that the AmTRZAc ligand undergoes decarboxylation to generate AmTRZ under hydrothermal reaction conditions. After reaction, the products were filtered, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried in air.

elements.content: The phase purity and crystallinity of each product were checked by powder XRD using a Scintag PAD-X diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). A step size of 0.02° and counting time of 1.2 s/step were applied in a 2θ range of 5.00−50.00°. The observed and simulated powder XRD patterns of all compounds are displayed in Figure . Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet Nexus 670 FT-IR spectrometer on KBr pellets in the range of 4000−650 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Netzsch STA 449C instrument. Each sample was heated from room temperature to 750 °C in air with a heating rate of 5.0 °C/min. Elemental analysis of 4 was performed by Galbraith Laboratories.

elements.content: Synthesis of ZnCl(AmTRZ) (1). Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 g, 1 mmol), AmTRZAc (0.38 g, 3 mmol), and HCl (1.0 M, 0.25 mL, 0.25 mmol) were added to water (6.00 g, 333 mmol). The pH of the solution was 2.0. The mixture was heated at 150 °C for 3 days. The products consisted of small colorless plates of 20−40 μm in dimension. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3391 (b), 3132 (w), 1627 (s), 1560 (s), 1428 (m), 1309 (s), 1231 (s), 1117 (w), 1073 (m), 1022 (w), 881 (m), 768 (w), 745 (m).

The pH of the reactant mixture was 3.7. The reactants were heated at 130 °C for 3 days. The products consisted of tiny, colorless plates of 20−50 μm in dimension. elements.content: Synthesis of Zn 5 (OH) 2 (AmTRZ) 6 (NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (3). In a typical reaction, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.89 g, 3 mmol), AmTRZAc (0.57 g, 4.5 mmol), and triethylamine (TEA) (0.37 g, 3.7 mmol) were added to water (6.00 g, 333 mmol). The pH of the reactants was 3.7. After reacting at 130 °C for 3 days, yellow octahedron-shaped crystals of ∼50 μm in size were recovered as products. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3343 (b), 1752 (w), 1623 (s), 1554 (s), 1384 (m), 1228 (m), 1161 (w), 1055 (m), 875 (w), 755 (m).

elements.content: Crystal Structure Determination. Because of small dimensions of the crystals, data collection and structure determination were carried out using a Bruker Platinum 200 instrument at 11.3.1 beamline at Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. All data were collected at 190 K with a wavelength of 0.7749 Å using the ω scan mode. The raw intensity data were collected with a software package Bruker APEX-2 suite. The collected data were integrated with SAINT, and then an empirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS. All four structures were solved by direct method and refined by full matrix least-squares based on F 2 with SHELXTL software package. Zinc and oxygen atoms were located first, and the remaining atoms were found by difference Fourier syntheses. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were added using geometrical constraints (HFIX command), where possible. However, the hydrogens on the waters could be neither placed nor found in the difference map and were therefore omitted from the refinement. The details of crystallographic data and refinement are given in Table . Selected bond lengths are displayed in Table .

The unit cell of 4 contains heavily disordered water and counteranion molecules. After assignment of the framework species, a number of residual electron density peaks were observed inside the channels. The distribution of these peaks was chemically meaningless; thus, the identity or location, except for one unit of formate anion, could not be identified as discrete atomic sites. The positions of water molecules and formate ions were modeled with geometrical constraints.

elements.content: Structural Description of 1 and 2. The crystal structures of isomorphous ZnCl(AmTRZ) (1) and Zn(HCO2)(AmTRZ) (2) are depicted in Figure . The major difference between two compounds is the type of counteranion. Compound 1 contains Cl- ion, incorporated from the addition of HCl. In 2, the formate anion (HCO2 -) resulting from decarboxylation of AmTRZAc is incorporated into the structure. The asymmetric unit consists of one unique Zn center, one AmTRZ, and one anion (Cl- and formate for 1 and 2, respectively). The AmTRZ ligand is deprotonated to provide an additional negative charge, which is necessary for charge balance. The Zn atom is in tetrahedral coordination by bonding three N atoms from the triazole ring and one Cl- or formate. The Zn−N bond distances are in the range of 1.992(3)−2.008(3) Å and 2.000(3)−2.017(3) Å for 1 and 2, respectively. The Zn−Cl bond length is 2.221(1) Å in 1, while the Zn−O length is 1.971(3) Å in 2. The bond valence sum around Zn was calculated to be 2.17 and 2.05 for 1 and 2, respectively, which is consistent with the oxidation state of Zn2+, suggesting all bonds around Zn are properly assigned. In 1, the AmTRZ ligand, which lies on a 2-fold pseudo-rotational axis, is disordered, resulting in two possible orientations of the amino group (see Figure S1 in Supporing Information). This type of ligand disorder was also observed in ZnF(AmTRZ). No such disorder is seen in 2; this can be attributed to the asymmetric formate groups on the apex of Zn tetrahedra preventing the existence of a pseudo-symmetry element.

Results and Discussion

 Structural Description of 1 and 2. The crystal structures of isomorphous ZnCl(AmTRZ) (1) and Zn(HCO2)(AmTRZ) (2) are depicted in Figure . The major difference between two  compounds is the type of counteranion. Compound 1 contains Cl- ion, incorporated from the addition of HCl. In 2, the formate anion (HCO2 -) resulting from decarboxylation of AmTRZAc is incorporated into the structure. The asymmetric unit consists of one unique Zn center, one AmTRZ, and one anion (Cl- and formate for 1 and 2, respectively). The AmTRZ ligand is deprotonated to provide an additional negative charge, which is necessary for charge balance. The Zn atom is in tetrahedral coordination by bonding three N atoms from the triazole ring and one Cl- or formate. The Zn-N bond distances are in the range of 1.992(3)-2.008(3) Å and 2.000(3)-2.017(3) Å for 1 and 2, respectively. The Zn-Cl bond length is 2.221(1) Å in 1, while the Zn-O length is 1.971(3) Å in 2. The bond valence sum around Zn was calculated to be 2.17 and 2.05 for 1 and 2, respectively, which is consistent with the oxidation state of Zn2+, suggesting all bonds around Zn are properly assigned. In 1, the AmTRZ ligand, which lies on a 2-fold pseudo-rotational axis, is disordered, resulting in two possible orientations of the amino group (see Figure S1 in Supporing Information). This type of ligand disorder was also observed in ZnF(AmTRZ). No such disorder is seen in 2; this can be attributed to the asymmetric formate groups on the apex of Zn tetrahedra preventing the existence of a pseudo-symmetry element.

elements.content: The structure of 1 and 2 is built from two-dimensional (2D) gridlike layers of Zn−AmTRZ along the (001) direction. The layer consists of eight-membered rings of alternating Zn tetrahedra and AmTRZ (Figure b). The dimension of the ring is approximately 3.30 × 3.21 Å2 for both compounds, considering the van der Waals radii of Zn atoms. The layers are stacked in a zigzag fashion such that the eight-membered rings are interpenetrated. The distance between two neighboring layers is slightly larger in 2, as reflected in the unit cell dimension along the c-axis (12.58 vs 11.57 Å) probably due to the repulsion between uncoordinated carboxyl O atoms between two layers. The anions (Cl- and HCO2 -) and amino groups, both pointing outward from the Zn−AmTRZ layer, interact with each other via weak hydrogen bonding (Cl···H−N and O···H−N distances = 3.29 and 2.92 Å, respectively).

elements.content: Structural Description of 3. The structure of Zn5(OH)2(AmTRZ)6(NO3)2·6H2O (3) is displayed in Figure . The unit cell contains three crystallographically independent Zn atoms. Zn(1) and Zn(2) are tetrahedrally coordinated by bonding to one OH- and three N atoms. Zn(3) lies in an octahedral coordination by bonding to six N atoms. The Zn−O bond lengths range from 1.858(7) to 1.999(3) Å, while the Zn−N bond distances are in the range of 1.999(3) to 2.198(2) Å. The bond valence calculations30 revealed that Zn(1) and Zn(2) are slightly overbonded with bond valence sums of 2.22 and 2.19, respectively. The Zn(3) atom shows a sum of 1.89, which is closer to the expected value of 2. The bond valence sum of 1.23 for the bridging oxygen indicates that this atom should be a hydroxyl group.

elements.content: The structure of 3 is a dense three-dimensional (3D) framework containing unsymmetrical, seven-membered rings (Figure b). These channels are made of three Zn tetrahedra, one Zn octahedron, and three AmTRZ ligands. Two Zn tetrahedra are linked directly to each other via a Zn(1)−OH−Zn(2) bridge. The dimension of the ring is approximately 3.22 × 3.56 Å. The uncoordinating amino groups protrude inside the channels, effectively reducing the porosity. The framework is positively charged (+2), and nitrate anions in the pores serve as counter anions. There are moderate hydrogen bonding interactions between nitrates and solvent water molecules with an Ow−H···O distance of 2.72 Å. A preliminary ion exchange study was carried out in an attempt to replace NO3 - with Cl- ions. A small amount (∼50 mg) of the powdered sample was immersed in 50 mL of 0.1 M NaCl solution for 3 days at room temperature. However, no changes in peak positions and intensities were observed in powder XRD data, suggesting that the ion exchange did not take place. More thorough experiments will be performed to assess the ion exchange capacity of 3.

elements.content: Structural Description of 4. The chemical formula of 4 could not be accurately determined from single-crystal XRD. The severe disorder of guest species (counterions and water molecules) could not be resolved, even with high-resolution synchrotron X-ray data at low temperature. From the Fourier difference map, only one unit of HCO2 - was identified without any ambiguity. Elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis were performed on the crystals from the same reaction batch. On the basis of these results, the chemical formula was estimated to be [Zn5(OH)(AmTRZH)(AmTRZ)6](HCO2)3·5H2O.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 4 contains four crystallographically independent Zn centers. All Zn atoms are tetrahedrally coordinated, except Zn(2), which displays an octahedral geometry. The Zn−N bond distances are in the range of 1.955(3)−2.266(3) Å, while the Zn−O bond distances are 1.908(4)−1.931(4) Å. The bond valence sums30 around tetrahedral Zn centers are somewhat higher (2.22−2.27) than expected, implying the presence of some strain in the structure. The octahedral Zn(2) shows a more satisfactory bond valence sum of 1.94. The identity of bridging μ2-OH- anion was also confirmed by the bond valence calculation around O atom (BVS = 1.12).

elements.content: The cationic [Zn5(OH)(AmTRZH)(AmTRZ)6]3+ framework is a complex 3D structure. It is based on the gridlike layers and dinuclear tetrahedral Zn building units (Figure a). The layer is constructed from isolated Zn(1)N4 and Zn(2)N6 polyhedra which are connected via AmTRZ ligands. As seen in Figure b, the linkage between Zn polyhedra and AmTRZ rings within the layer generates 8- and 12-membered channels in the ab plane. The dimensions of these channels are approximately 3.21 × 3.22 Å2 and 8.83 × 8.83 Å, taking the van der Waals radii into account. The second building unit, shown in Figure c, is made from two pairs of corner-sharing dinuclear Zn(3) and Zn(4) tetrahedra and two AmTRZH ligands to create a six-membered ring. This AmTRZ ligand is probably not deprotonated (thus denoted as AmTRZH), since the nitrogen in the 1 position is not coordinated to a Zn center. This ligand is also 2-fold disordered (see Figure S2 in Supporting Information); two disordered components are related by a mirror plane that lies perpendicular to the c-axis. As two adjacent layers are linked by the substructural units along the c-axis, the 12-membered channels become obstructed. Moreover, the uncoordinating amino groups from AmTRZ protrude inside these voids, leaving only the eight-membered rings open. The charge-balancing formate ions and solvent water molecules are located in the interlamellar regions between substructures.

elements.content: The potential solvent accessible volume of 4 was estimated to 2423 Å, which constitutes approximately 32% of the unit cell volume. Although compound 4 appears to be microporous, it exhibited insignificant sorption characteristics. A preliminary hydrogen gas sorption measurement of the outgassed sample (100 °C for 13.5 h under vacuum) resulted in the uptake of only 0.1 wt % at 77 K and 1 atm. The poor sorption capacity probably arises from the difficulties in removing guest molecules without destroying the framework due to its low thermal stability, as discussed below. Further, the above outgassing condition may have not been sufficient to remove all solvents; however, the framework may disintegrate if it was heated at higher temperatures.

elements.content: Thermal Properties. Thermogravimetric data of 1−4 are plotted in Figure . Compound 1 displays a high thermal stability, as there is very little weight loss up to 400 °C. An abrupt weight loss between 420 and 650 °C suggests the framework breakdown due to the decomposition of the AmTRZ ligands (observed:  32.3 wt %, calculated:  35.5 wt %). In spite of being isostructural to 1, compound 2 is stable only up to ∼250 °C before the framework gradually collapses between 270 and 700 °C (observed:  49.8 wt %, calculated:  45.1 wt %). The decomposition of formate probably has probably triggered the breakdown of the framework. The TGA curve of 3 shows a steady weight loss of organic components from 100 to 730 °C (observed:  61.6 wt %, calculated:  62.7 wt %) without any well-defined plateau. For 4, the first event takes place between 50 and 260 °C, which can be assigned to the removal of water molecules (observed:  9.0 wt %, calculated:  7.9 wt %). The curve shows a very small region of plateau between 260 and 300 °C before a rapid weight loss occurs, implying the immediate structural collapse upon the removal of water. The second weight loss between 300 and 720 °C can be attributed to the decomposition of the formates and organic linkers (observed:  64.2 wt %, calculated:  64.4 wt %).

elements.content: Discussion. The coordination chemistry of metal−AmTRZ is rich and diverse, as exemplified by a number of unique frameworks in the literature, including ZnF(AmTRZ), CdCl(AmTRZ), and Ag6Cl(AmTRZ)4(OH). Despite the similarities in their chemical formulas, ZnF(AmTRZ) and CdCl(AmTRZ) exhibit very different architectures from compounds 1 and 2. The structure of ZnF(AmTRZ) displays a hollow nanotubular channels formed by six Zn centers and six AmTRZ, while CdCl(AmTRZ) is a chiral 3D framework where all N atoms from the ligand, including the amino group, are coordinated to metal centers. Ag6Cl(AmTRZ)4(OH) is an interpenetrated framework with 16- and 8-membered channels running along the (001) direction. In all three structures, the construction of a 3D framework is achieved through bridging halide anions to link two metal centers. The metal ions also adopt larger coordination environments (octahedral or trigonal bipyramidal). For 1 and 2, the construction of an open framework may be possible if the coordination number of Zn was increased to achieve a Zn−anion−Zn bridging mode.
elements.clean_text: Discussion. The coordination chemistry of metal-AmTRZ is rich and diverse, as exemplified by a number of unique frameworks in the literature, including ZnF(AmTRZ), CdCl(AmTRZ), and Ag6Cl(AmTRZ)4(OH). Despite the similarities in their chemical formulas, ZnF(AmTRZ) and CdCl(AmTRZ) exhibit very different architectures from compounds 1 and 2. The structure of ZnF(AmTRZ) displays a hollow nanotubular channels formed by six Zn centers and six AmTRZ, while CdCl(AmTRZ) is a chiral 3D framework where all N atoms from the ligand, including the amino group, are coordinated to metal centers. Ag6Cl(AmTRZ)4(OH) is an interpenetrated framework with 16- and 8-membered channels running along the (001) direction. In all three structures, the construction of a 3D framework is achieved through bridging halide anions to link two metal centers. The metal ions also adopt larger coordination environments (octahedral or trigonal bipyramidal). For 1 and 2, the construction of an open framework may be possible if the coordination number of Zn was increased to achieve a Zn-anion-Zn bridging mode.

elements.content: In all four compounds, the deprotonation of AmTRZ ligand was observed, except one AmTRZ in structure 4. Although the dissociation of the ligands is not favored under acidic conditions, triazole and its derivatives often get incorporated in coordination polymers as deprotonated forms. It has been proposed that a shift in pK a of the ligand takes place under hydrothermal conditions favoring the loss of hydrogen.

elements.content: The study of Zn−AmTRZ frameworks illustrates the importance of the fine-tuning of the reaction parameters in MOF syntheses. By simply varying reactant ratio (Zn/AmTRZ/solvent) and pH, three new structure-types were produced. Each structure features distinct Zn−ligand connectivity, which directs the development of either a layer or a 3D framework. The presence of different charge-balancing anions (Cl-, HCO2 -, NO3 -) in these structures also suggests that the identity of the counterion may also play a significant role on the architecture of the resulting compound. It is not a simple task to probe the processes that take place during the formation of porous materials under hydrothermal conditions. The use of in situ time-resolved diffraction or spectroscopic methods can provide valuable insights on the effects of a particular reaction variable. In addition, the application of high-throughput techniques can be very helpful to speed up the experimental processes by running and analyzing many reactions at once.

elements.content: This study investigated the synthesis of metal−organic frameworks using Zn2+ ions and 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole under solvothermal conditions. Four new compounds were discovered by simply varying reactant compositions. Isostructural compounds 1 and 2 are based on 2D sheets created by eight-membered Zn−AmTRZ channels. Compound 3 is a dense 3D framework containing seven-membered Zn−AmTRZ rings. Compound 4 is built from porous 2D layers that are bridged by dimeric Zn building units. Because the frameworks of 3 and 4 are positively charged, it may be of great interest to carry out anion-exchange studies. Because of a large number of parameters involved, it remains a great challenge to understand the relationship between the reaction conditions and the construction of a desired structure. More rational design of MOFs can be accomplished by a careful control of reaction variables using in situ techniques and combinatorial synthesis methods.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

This study investigated the synthesis of metal-organic frameworks using Zn2+ ions and 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole under solvothermal conditions. Four new compounds were discovered by simply varying reactant compositions. Isostructural compounds 1 and 2 are based on 2D sheets created by eight-membered Zn-AmTRZ channels. Compound 3 is a dense 3D framework containing seven-membered Zn-AmTRZ rings. Compound 4 is built from porous 2D layers that are bridged by dimeric Zn building units. Because the frameworks of 3 and 4 are positively charged, it may be of great interest to carry out anion-exchange studies. Because of a large number of parameters involved, it remains a great challenge to understand the relationship between the reaction conditions and the construction of a desired structure. More rational design of MOFs can be accomplished by a careful control of reaction variables using in situ techniques and combinatorial synthesis methods.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of ZnCl(AmTRZ) (1). Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 g, 1 mmol), AmTRZAc (0.38 g, 3 mmol), and HCl (1.0 M, 0.25 mL, 0.25 mmol) were added to water (6.00 g, 333 mmol). The pH of the solution was 2.0. The mixture was heated at 150 °C for 3 days. The products consisted of small colorless plates of 20−40 μm in dimension. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3391 (b), 3132 (w), 1627 (s), 1560 (s), 1428 (m), 1309 (s), 1231 (s), 1117 (w), 1073 (m), 1022 (w), 881 (m), 768 (w), 745 (m).

Synthesis of Zn(HCO 2 )(AmTRZ) (2). Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.60 g, 2 mmol), AmTRZAc (0.77 g, 6 mmol), and TEA (0.37 g, 3.7 mmol) were added to dimethylformamide (DMF) (6.00 g, 82.1 mmol). The pH of the reactant mixture was 3.7. The reactants were heated at 130 °C for 3 days. The products consisted of tiny, colorless plates of 20−50 μm in dimension. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3483 (s), 3225 (b), 2850 (s), 1620 (s), 1529 (s), 1429 (w), 1369(w), 1326 (m), 1226 (m), 1111 (w), 1051 (m), 1018 (w), 905 (m), 787 (m).

Synthesis of Zn 5 (OH) 2 (AmTRZ) 6 (NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (3). In a typical reaction, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.89 g, 3 mmol), AmTRZAc (0.57 g, 4.5 mmol), and triethylamine (TEA) (0.37 g, 3.7 mmol) were added to water (6.00 g, 333 mmol). The pH of the reactants was 3.7. After reacting at 130 °C for 3 days, yellow octahedron-shaped crystals of ∼50 μm in size were recovered as products. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3343 (b), 1752 (w), 1623 (s), 1554 (s), 1384 (m), 1228 (m), 1161 (w), 1055 (m), 875 (w), 755 (m).

Synthesis of Zn 5 (OH)(AmTRZH)(AmTRZ) 6 (HCO 2 ) 3 ·5H 2 O (4). Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.60 g, 2 mmol), AmTRZAc (0.77 g, 6 mmol), and TEA (0.37 g, 3.7 mmol) were mixed with water (6.00 g, 333 mmol). The pH of the reactants was 4.3. The reaction mixture was heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the reaction, colorless prisms (40−50 μm in dimension) and a small amount of yellowish powder were obtained. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3361 (b), 1633 (s), 1556 (s), 1328 (m), 1221 (w), 1158 (w), 1060 (m), 850 (m), 752 (m), 661 (m). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C17H29N28O12Zn5:  C 17.2, H 3.2, N 35.2. Found:  C 17.8, H 2.6, N 34.3.

cln_elements.content:
Four new coordination polymer compounds have been prepared using 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (AmTRZ) as an organic linker, namely, ZnCl(AmTRZ) (1), Zn(HCO2)(AmTRZ) (2), Zn5(OH)2(AmTRZ)6(NO3)2·6H2O (3), and Zn5(OH)(AmTRZH)(AmTRZ)6(HCO2)3·5H2O (4). They were synthesized under mild hydro- or solvothermal conditions using water or dimethylformamide as solvent. Their crystal structures were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques, and thermal properties of all compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis. Isostructural compounds 1 and 2 (Pbca, a = 9.389(1) Å, b = 10.115(1) Å, c = 11.571(2) Å, V = 1098.9(3) Å3, Z = 8 for 1 and a = 9.198(1) Å, b = 10.341(1) Å, c = 12.577(2) Å, V = 1196.2(3) Å, Z = 8 for 2) display a two-dimensional layer structure where Zn centers are linked by AmTRZ molecules to form gridlike layers containing eight-membered rings. Structure 3 (Pa3̄, a = 15.0448(6) Å, V = 3405.3(2) Å3, Z = 4) is a dense three-dimensional framework, featuring seven-membered channels where water and nitrate anions are located. Structure 4 (I4/m, a = 19.2576(9) Å, c = 20.286(2) Å, V = 7523.2(9) Å3, Z = 8) is built from porous Zn−AmTRZ layers containing 12- and 8-membered rings, which are connected to each other by dinuclear Zn tetrahedra building units. Water and formate anions occupy the void inside the framework.

The potential solvent accessible volume of 4 was estimated to 2423 Å, which constitutes approximately 32% of the unit cell volume. Although compound 4 appears to be microporous, it exhibited insignificant sorption characteristics. A preliminary hydrogen gas sorption measurement of the outgassed sample (100 °C for 13.5 h under vacuum) resulted in the uptake of only 0.1 wt % at 77 K and 1 atm. The poor sorption capacity probably arises from the difficulties in removing guest molecules without destroying the framework due to its low thermal stability, as discussed below. Further, the above outgassing condition may have not been sufficient to remove all solvents; however, the framework may disintegrate if it was heated at higher temperatures.

Thermal Properties. Thermogravimetric data of 1−4 are plotted in Figure . Compound 1 displays a high thermal stability, as there is very little weight loss up to 400 °C. An abrupt weight loss between 420 and 650 °C suggests the framework breakdown due to the decomposition of the AmTRZ ligands (observed:  32.3 wt %, calculated:  35.5 wt %). In spite of being isostructural to 1, compound 2 is stable only up to ∼250 °C before the framework gradually collapses between 270 and 700 °C (observed:  49.8 wt %, calculated:  45.1 wt %). The decomposition of formate probably has probably triggered the breakdown of the framework. The TGA curve of 3 shows a steady weight loss of organic components from 100 to 730 °C (observed:  61.6 wt %, calculated:  62.7 wt %) without any well-defined plateau. For 4, the first event takes place between 50 and 260 °C, which can be assigned to the removal of water molecules (observed:  9.0 wt %, calculated:  7.9 wt %). The curve shows a very small region of plateau between 260 and 300 °C before a rapid weight loss occurs, implying the immediate structural collapse upon the removal of water. The second weight loss between 300 and 720 °C can be attributed to the decomposition of the formates and organic linkers (observed:  64.2 wt %, calculated:  64.4 wt %).
